Name: Warm lowlands
Description: Relatively warm, flat/level ecosystems, often coastal but not always. Elevations low and topography is gentle. May be rocky and barren, but often hosts bird colonies and pinnipeds if occurring near the coast.

Name: Midland humid ecosystems
Description: Occurs on somewhat rugged terrain at low-to-mid elevations, usually near or directly on the coast. Dominates the mountainous areas of the Antarctic peninsula, with representation in the Ellsworth mountains and the westernmost end of the Transantarctic mountains. Characterised by high cloud cover and precipitation, relatively high temperatures because of low elevation. Thick snow cover (probably seasonal) remains on the surfaces, which are mostly not steep enough for the snow to slide down. Biota consists mainly of mosses and lichens.

Name: High cliffs, crags, mountainsides, and slopes
Description: High elevation, extremely cold, arid, and rugged ecosystems. Good representation in all mountainous areas, sprinkled among other ecosystems where steep slopes are present. Slopes are too steep to hold snow layer and are typically barren rock with very little biota. [13] and [15] cover rugged areas of the peninsula, and all subunits occur in the Transantarctic mountains.

Name: Highland windy plateaus and outcrops
Description: Consists of cold, arid, windy, high-elevation flatlands/plateaus/rounded hills (low ruggedness) with low cloud and high radiation due to north facing rock faces. [19] and [21] are relatively lower wind, the others are high wind. This is the dominant environment type in North Victoria Land and the inland of Enderby land and the Prince Charles Mountains.

Name: High, inland hills and outcrops
Description: Cold, arid, Mid-to-high elevation and mid-to-low ruggedness highlands with low wind, south facing slopes, and average cloudiness.

Name: Islands
Description: Coastal and island pixels lacking neighboring terrestrial pixels.
